intro: Drakea, commonly known as the New Zealand flax, is a genus of flowering plants in the family Asphodelaceae. It is native to New Zealand and consists of several species, including Drakea discolor and Drakea lanata. These plants are characterized by their fibrous leaves, which are used for traditional weaving by Māori people. Drakea species typically grow in coastal and lowland areas, preferring well-drained soils and full sun. They play an important ecological role in their native habitat, providing habitat and food for various native wildlife.
